items.name: show
items.text:
Shows this Component, rendering it first if {@link #cfg!autoRender #autoRender} or {@link #cfg!floating #cfg-floating} are `true`.

After being shown, a {@link #cfg!floating #cfg-floating} Component (such as a {@link Ext.window.Window}), is activated it and
brought to the front of its {@link #property!zIndexManager #zIndexManager}.

items.name: animateTarget
items.text:
**only valid for {@link #cfg!floating #cfg-floating} Components such as {@link Ext.window.Window}s or {@link Ext.tip.ToolTip}s, or regular Components which have been configured
with `floating: true`.** The target from which the Component should animate from while opening.

items.name: callback
items.text:
A callback function to call after the Component is displayed.
Only necessary if animation was specified.

items.name: scope
items.text:
The scope (`this` reference) in which the callback is executed.
Defaults to this Component.
this

items.name: showAt
x
items.text: The new x position or array of `[x,y]`.

items.name: y
items.text: The new y position

items.name: animate
items.text:
True to animate the Component into its new position. You may also pass an
animation configuration.
this

items.name: showBy
items.text:
Shows this component by the specified {@link Ext.Component} or {@link Ext.dom.Element}.
Used when this component is {@link #cfg!floating #cfg-floating}.

items.name: component
items.text: The {@link Ext.Component} or {@link Ext.dom.Element} to show the component by.

items.name: position
items.text:
Alignment position as used by {@link Ext.util.Positionable#method!getAlignToXY Ext.util.Positionable#getAlignToXY}.
Defaults to `{@link #cfg!defaultAlign #defaultAlign}`. See {@link #method!alignTo #alignTo} for possible values.

items.name: offsets
items.text: Alignment offsets as used by {@link Ext.util.Positionable#method!getAlignToXY Ext.util.Positionable#getAlignToXY}. See {@link #method!alignTo #alignTo} for possible values.
this

items.name: showGroupByText
items.text: The container has an info text displayed inside. This function makes it visible.

items.name: slideOutFloatedPanelBegin
items.text: This method begins the slide out of the floated panel.

items.name: slideOutFloatedPanelEnd
items.text: This method cleans up after the slide out of the floated panel.

items.name: statics
stopAnimation
items.text:
Stops any running effects and clears this object's internal effects queue if it contains any additional effects
that haven't started yet.
The Element

items.name: stopFx
items.text:
Stops any running effects and clears this object's internal effects queue if it contains any additional effects
that haven't started yet.
The Element

items.name: suspendEvent
items.text:
Suspends firing of the named event(s).

After calling this method to suspend events, the events will no longer fire when requested to fire.

**Note that if this is called multiple times for a certain event, the converse method
{@link #method!resumeEvent #resumeEvent} will have to be called the same number of times for it to resume firing.**

items.name: eventName
items.text: Multiple event names to suspend.

items.name: suspendEvents
items.text: Suspends the firing of all events. (see {@link #method!resumeEvents #resumeEvents})

items.name: queueSuspended
items.text:
`true` to queue up suspended events to be fired
after the {@link #method!resumeEvents #resumeEvents} call instead of discarding all suspended events.

items.name: syncFx
items.text:
Ensures that all effects queued after syncFx is called on this object are run concurrently. This is the opposite
of {@link #method!sequenceFx #sequenceFx}.
this

items.name: syncHidden
items.text: synchronizes the hidden state of this component with the state of its hierarchy

items.name: toBack
items.text: Sends this Component to the back of (lower z-index than) any other visible windows
this

items.name: toFront
preventFocus
items.text: Specify `true` to prevent the Component from being focused.
this

items.name: toggleCollapse
items.text: Shortcut for performing an {@link #method!expand #method-expand} or {@link #method!collapse #method-collapse} based on the current state of the panel.
this

items.name: toLocaleString
items.text:
Returns a string representing the object. This method is meant to be overridden by derived objects
for locale-specific purposes.

`{@link Object}`'s `{@link #method!toLocaleString toLocaleString}` returns the result of calling `{@link #method!toString toString}`.

This function is provided to give objects a generic `{@link #method!toLocaleString toLocaleString}` method, even though not all
may use it. Currently, only `{@link Array}`, `{@link Number}`, and `{@link Date}` override `{@link #method!toLocaleString toLocaleString}`.
Object represented as a string.

items.name: toString

items.text: Object represented as a string.

items.name: translatePoints
items.text: Translates the passed page coordinates into left/top css values for the element

items.name: x
items.text: The page x or an array containing [x, y]

items.name: y
items.text: The page y, required if x is not an array

An object with left and top properties. e.g.
{left: (value), top: (value)}

items.name: translateXY
items.text: Translates the passed page coordinates into x and y css values for the element

items.name: x
items.text: The page x or an array containing [x, y]

items.name: y
items.text: The page y, required if x is not an array

An object with x and y properties. e.g.
{x: (value), y: (value)}

items.name: un
items.text: Shorthand for {@link #method!removeListener #removeListener}.

items.name: unAfter
items.text:
Removes a before-event handler.

Same as {@link #method!removeListener #removeListener} with `order` set to `'after'`.

items.name: eventName
items.text: The name of the event the handler was associated with.

items.name: fn
items.text: The handler to remove.

items.name: scope
items.text: The scope originally specified for `fn`.

items.name: options
items.text: Extra options object.

items.name: unBefore
items.text:
Removes a before-event handler.

Same as {@link #method!removeListener #removeListener} with `order` set to `'before'`.

items.name: eventName
items.text: The name of the event the handler was associated with.

items.name: fn
items.text: The handler to remove.

items.name: scope
items.text: The scope originally specified for `fn`.

items.name: options
items.text: Extra options object.

items.name: unlink
items.text:
Destroys a given set of `{@link #method!link #link}` objects. This is only needed if
the linked object is being destroyed before this instance.

items.name: names
items.text: The names of the linked objects to destroy.
this

items.name: unmask
items.text: Removes the mask applied by {@link #method!mask #mask}

items.name: up
items.text:
Navigates up the ownership hierarchy searching for an ancestor Container which matches any passed selector or component.

*Important.* There is not a universal upwards navigation pointer. There are several upwards relationships
such as the {@link Ext.button.Button} which activates a {@link Ext.button.Button#cfg!menu Ext.button.Button#cfg-menu}, or the
{@link Ext.menu.Item} which activated a {@link Ext.menu.Item#cfg!menu Ext.menu.Item#cfg-menu}, or the
{@link Ext.grid.column.Column} which activated the column menu.

These differences are abstracted away by this method.

Example:

    var owningTabPanel = grid.up('tabpanel');

items.name: selector
items.text: The selector component or actual component to test. If not passed the immediate owner/activator is returned.

items.name: limit
items.text: This may be a selector upon which to stop the upward scan, or a limit of the number of steps, or Component reference to stop on.
The matching ancestor Container (or `{@link undefined}` if no match was found).

items.name: update
items.text: Update the content area of a component.

items.name: htmlOrData
items.text:
If this component has been configured with a
template via the tpl config then it will use this argument as data to populate the
template. If this component was not configured with a template, the components
content area will be updated via Ext.Element update.

items.name: loadScripts
items.text:
Only legitimate when using the `{@link #cfg!html html}`
configuration. Causes embedded script tags to be executed. Inline source will be executed
with this Component as the scope (`this` reference).

items.name: callback
items.text:
Only legitimate when using the `{@link #cfg!html html}` configuration.
Callback to execute when scripts have finished loading.

items.name: scriptScope
items.text:
The scope (`this` reference) in which to
execute *inline* script elements content. Scripts with a `src` attribute cannot
be executed with this scope.

items.name: updateBox
items.text: Sets the current box measurements of the component's underlying element.

items.name: box
items.text: An object in the format {x, y, width, height}
this

items.name: updateColumnIndexes
items.text: After a column is moved the indexes has to be updated.

items.name: updateFrame
items.text:
Updates the frame elements to match new framing. The current `frameBody` is
preserved by transplanting it into the new frame. All other frame `{@link #cfg!childEls childEls}`
are destroyed and recreated if needed by the new frame. This method cannot
transition from framed to non-framed or vise-versa or between table and div
based framing.

items.name: updateHeader
items.text: Create, hide, or show the header component as appropriate based on the current config.

items.name: force
items.text: True to force the header to be created

items.name: updateLayout
items.text:
Updates this component's layout. If this update affects this components {@link #property!ownerCt #ownerCt},
that component's `{@link #method!updateLayout updateLayout}` method will be called to perform the layout instead.
Otherwise, just this component (and its child items) will layout.

items.name: options
items.text: An object with layout options.

items.name: defer
items.text: `true` if this layout should be deferred.

items.name: isRoot
items.text: `true` if this layout should be the root of the layout.

items.name: updateSession
items.text: Updates the session config.

items.name: updateViewModel
items.text: Updates the viewModel config.

items.name: valueOf
items.text:
Returns the primitive value of the specified object.

JavaScript calls the `{@link #method!valueOf valueOf}` method to convert an object to a primitive value. You rarely need to
invoke the `{@link #method!valueOf valueOf}` method yourself; JavaScript automatically invokes it when encountering an
object where a primitive value is expected.

By default, the `{@link #method!valueOf valueOf}` method is inherited by every object descended from `{@link Object}`. Every built-
in core object overrides this method to return an appropriate value. If an object has no primitive
value, `{@link #method!valueOf valueOf}` returns the object itself, which is displayed as:

    [object Object]

You can use `{@link #method!valueOf valueOf}` within your own code to convert a built-in object into a primitive value.
When you create a custom object, you can override `Object.valueOf` to call a custom method instead
of the default `{@link Object}` method.

You can create a function to be called in place of the default `{@link #method!valueOf valueOf}` method. Your function must
take no arguments.

Suppose you have an object type `myNumberType` and you want to create a `{@link #method!valueOf valueOf}` method for it.
The following code assigns a user-defined function to the object's valueOf method:

    myNumberType.prototype.valueOf = new Function(functionText)

With the preceding code in place, any time an object of type `myNumberType` is used in a context
where it is to be represented as a primitive value, JavaScript automatically calls the function
defined in the preceding code.

An object's `{@link #method!valueOf valueOf}` method is usually invoked by JavaScript, but you can invoke it yourself as
follows:

    myNumber.valueOf()

Note: Objects in string contexts convert via the `{@link #method!toString toString}` method, which is different from
`{@link String}` objects converting to string primitives using `{@link #method!valueOf valueOf}`. All objects have a string
conversion, if only `"[object type]"`. But many objects do not convert to number, boolean, or
function.
Returns value of the object or the object itself.

items.name: visitPostOrder
items.text:
Traverses the tree rooted at this node in post-order mode, calling the passed function on the nodes at each level.
That is the function is called upon each node **after** being called on its children).

This method is used at each level down the cascade. Currently {@link Ext.Component}s
and {@link Ext.data.TreeModel}s are queryable.

If you have tree-structured data, you can make your nodes queryable, and use ComponentQuery on them.

items.name: selector
items.text:
A ComponentQuery selector used to filter candidate nodes before calling the function.
An empty string matches any node.

items.name: fn
items.text: The function to call. Return `false` to aborl the traverse.

items.name: node
items.text: The node being visited.

items.name: scope
items.text: The context (`this` reference) in which the function is executed.

items.name: extraArgs
items.text:
A set of arguments to be appended to the function's argument list to pass down extra data known to the caller
**after** the node being visited.

items.name: visitPreOrder
items.text:
Traverses the tree rooted at this node in pre-order mode, calling the passed function on the nodes at each level.
That is the function is called upon each node **before** being called on its children).

This method is used at each level down the cascade. Currently {@link Ext.Component}s
and {@link Ext.data.TreeModel}s are queryable.

If you have tree-structured data, you can make your nodes queryable, and use ComponentQuery on them.

items.name: selector
items.text:
A ComponentQuery selector used to filter candidate nodes before calling the function.
An empty string matches any node.

items.name: fn
items.text: The function to call. Return `false` to aborl the traverse.

items.name: node
items.text: The node being visited.

items.name: scope
items.text: The context (`this` reference) in which the function is executed.

items.name: extraArgs
items.text:
A set of arguments to be appended to the function's argument list to pass down extra data known to the caller
**after** the node being visited.

items.name: $configPrefixed
items.text:
The value `true` causes `config` values to be stored on instances using a
property name prefixed with an underscore ("_") character. A value of `false`
stores `config` values as properties using their exact name (no prefix).

items.name: $configStrict
items.text:
The value `true` instructs the `{@link #method!initConfig initConfig}` method to only honor values for
properties declared in the `config` block of a class. When `false`, properties
that are not declared in a `config` block will be placed on the instance.

items.name: $eventOptions
items.text: Matches options property names within a listeners specification object  - property names which are never used as event names.

items.name: _isLayoutRoot
items.text:
Setting this property to `true` causes the {@link #method!isLayoutRoot #isLayoutRoot} method to return
`true` and stop the search for the top-most component for a layout.

items.name: _renderState
items.text:
This property holds one of the following values during the render process:

  * **0** - The component is not rendered.
  * **1** - The component has fired beforerender and is about to call beforeRender.
   The component has just started rendering.
  * **2** - The component has finished the `{@link #method!beforeRender beforeRender}` process and is about to
   call `{@link #method!onRender onRender}`. This is when `rendering` is set to `true`.
  * **3** - The component has started `{@link #method!onRender onRender}`. This is when `{@link #property!rendered rendered}` is set
   to `true`.
  * **4** - The component has finished its afterrender process.

items.name: addTools
items.text: Template method to be implemented in subclasses to add their tools after the collapsible tool.

items.name: ariaEl
items.text:
The name of the Component property that holds
a reference to the Element that serves as that Component's ARIA element.
This property will be replaced with the actual Element reference after rendering.

Most of the simple Components will have their main element as ariaEl.

items.name: ariaRenderAttributes
items.text:
**Instance specific** ARIA attributes
to render into Component's ariaEl. This object is only used during rendering,
and is discarded afterwards.

items.name: ariaRole
items.text:
ARIA role for this Component, defaults to no role.
With no role, no other ARIA attributes are set.

items.name: autoGenId
items.text: `true` indicates an `{@link #cfg!id id}` was auto-generated rather than provided by configuration.

items.name: body
items.text:
The Panel's body {@link Ext.dom.Element} which may be used to contain HTML content.
The content may be specified in the {@link #cfg!html #html} config, or it may be loaded using the
{@link #cfg!loader #loader} config. Read-only.

If this is used to load visible HTML elements in either way, then
the Panel may not be used as a Layout for hosting nested Panels.

If this Panel is intended to be used as the host of a Layout (See {@link #cfg!layout #layout}
then the body Element must not be loaded or changed - it is under the control
of the Panel's Layout.

items.name: componentLayoutCounter
items.text: The number of component layout calls made on this object.

items.name: constructor
convertPositionSpec
items.text:
By default this method does nothing but return the position spec passed to it. In
rtl mode it is overridden to convert "l" to "r" and vice versa when required.

items.name: dd
items.text:
Only present if this Panel has been configured with {@link #cfg!draggable #cfg-draggable} `true`.

##Simple dragging##

If this Panel is configured {@link #cfg!simpleDrag #cfg-simpleDrag} `true` (the default is `false`), this property
will reference an instance of {@link Ext.util.ComponentDragger} (A subclass of
{@link Ext.dd.DragTracker}) which handles moving the Panel's DOM Element,
and constraining according to the {@link #cfg!constrain #constrain} and {@link #cfg!constrainHeader #constrainHeader} .

This object fires various events during its lifecycle and during a drag operation.

##Complex dragging interacting with other DragDrop instances##

By default, this property in a {@link #cfg!draggable #cfg-draggable} Panel will contain an instance of {@link Ext.dd.DragSource} which handles dragging the Panel.

The developer must provide implementations of the abstract methods of {@link Ext.dd.DragSource} in order to
supply behaviour for each stage of the drag/drop process.

See also {@link #cfg!draggable #cfg-draggable}.

items.name: defaultBindProperty
items.text:
This property is used to determine the property of a `{@link #cfg!bind bind}` config that is just
the value. For example, if `defaultBindProperty="value"`, then this shorthand
`{@link #cfg!bind bind}` config:

     bind: '{name}'

Is equivalent to this object form:

     bind: {
         value: '{name}'
     }

The `{@link #property!defaultBindProperty defaultBindProperty}` is set to "value" for form fields and to "store" for
grids and trees.

items.name: destroyed
items.text: This property is set to `true` after the `destroy` method is called.

items.name: dockOrder
items.text:
Values to decide which side of the body element docked items must go
This overides any weight. A left/top will *always* sort before a right/bottom
regardless of any weight value. Weights sort at either side of the "body" dividing point.

items.name: eventsSuspended
items.text: Initial suspended call count. Incremented when {@link #method!suspendEvents #suspendEvents} is called, decremented when {@link #method!resumeEvents #resumeEvents} is called.

items.name: floating
items.text: The value `true` indicates that this Component is floating.

items.name: floatingItems
items.text:
The MixedCollection containing all the floating child items of this container.
Will be `{@link undefined}` if there are no floating child items.

items.name: floatParent
items.text:
**Only present for {@link #cfg!floating #cfg-floating} Components which were inserted as child items of Containers.**

There are other similar relationships such as the {@link Ext.button.Button} which activates a {@link Ext.button.Button#cfg!menu Ext.button.Button#cfg-menu}, or the
{@link Ext.menu.Item} which activated a {@link Ext.menu.Item#cfg!menu Ext.menu.Item#cfg-menu}, or the
{@link Ext.grid.column.Column} which activated the column menu.

These differences are abstracted away by the {@link #method!up #up} method.

Floating Components that are programmatically {@link Ext.Component#method!render Ext.Component#method-render} will not have a `{@link #property!floatParent floatParent}`
property.

See {@link #cfg!floating #cfg-floating} and {@link #property!zIndexManager #zIndexManager}

items.name: focusable
items.text:
`true` for interactive Components, `false` for static Components.
For Containers, this property reflects interactiveness of the
Container itself, not its children. See {@link #method!isFocusable #isFocusable}.

**Note:** Plain components are static, so not focusable.

items.name: focusEl
items.text:
The component's focusEl.
Available after rendering.

items.name: frameSize
items.text:
Indicates the width of any framing elements which were added within the encapsulating
element to provide graphical, rounded borders. See the {@link #cfg!frame #frame} config. This
property is `{@link null}` if the component is not framed.

This is an object containing the frame width in pixels for all four sides of the
Component containing the following properties:

items.name: top
items.text: The width of the top framing element in pixels.

items.name: right
items.text: The width of the right framing element in pixels.

items.name: bottom
items.text: The width of the bottom framing element in pixels.

items.name: left
items.text: The width of the left framing element in pixels.

items.name: width
items.text: The total width of the left and right framing elements in pixels.

items.name: height
items.text: The total height of the top and right bottom elements in pixels.

items.name: hasFocus
items.text: `true` if this component has focus.

items.name: hasListeners
items.text:
This object holds a key for any event that has a listener. The listener may be set
directly on the instance, or on its class or a super class (via {@link #observe}) or
on the {@link Ext.app.EventBus}. The values of this object are truthy
(a non-zero number) and falsy (0 or undefined). They do not represent an exact count
of listeners. The value for an event is truthy if the event must be fired and is
falsy if there is no need to fire the event.

The intended use of this property is to avoid the expense of fireEvent calls when
there are no listeners. This can be particularly helpful when one would otherwise
have to call fireEvent hundreds or thousands of times. It is used like this:

     if (this.hasListeners.foo) {
         this.fireEvent('foo', this, arg1);
     }

items.name: horizontalDocks
items.text: Number of dock 'left' and 'right' items.

items.name: initFocusable
items.text:
Template method to do any Focusable related initialization that
does not involve event listeners creation.

items.name: initialConfig
items.text: The config object passed to the constructor during Component creation.

items.name: isComponent
items.text: `true` in this class to identify an object as an instantiated Component, or subclass thereof.

items.name: isConfiguring
items.text: This property is set to `true` during the call to `{@link #method!initConfig initConfig}`.

items.name: isContainer
items.text: `true` in this class to identify an object as an instantiated Container, or subclass thereof.

items.name: isFirstInstance
items.text: This property is set to `true` if this instance is the first of its class.

items.name: isInstance
items.text:
This value is `true` and is used to identify plain objects from instances of
a defined class.

items.name: isObservable
items.text: `true` in this class to identify an object as an instantiated Observable, or subclass thereof.

items.name: isPanel
items.text: `true` in this class to identify an object as an instantiated Panel, or subclass thereof.

items.name: items
items.text: The Collection containing all the child items of this container.

items.name: layoutCounter
items.text: The number of container layout calls made on this object.

items.name: maskOnDisable
items.text:
This is an internal flag that you use when creating custom components. By default this is set to `true` which means
that every component gets a mask when it's disabled. Components like FieldContainer, FieldSet, Field, Button, Tab
override this property to `false` since they want to implement custom disable logic.

items.name: ownerCt
items.text:
This Component's owner {@link Ext.container.Container} (is set automatically
when this Component is added to a Container).

*Important.* This is not a universal upwards navigation pointer. It indicates the Container which owns and manages
this Component if any. There are other similar relationships such as the {@link Ext.button.Button} which activates a {@link Ext.button.Button#cfg!menu Ext.button.Button#cfg-menu}, or the
{@link Ext.menu.Item} which activated a {@link Ext.menu.Item#cfg!menu Ext.menu.Item#cfg-menu}, or the
{@link Ext.grid.column.Column} which activated the column menu.

These differences are abstracted away by the {@link #method!up #up} method.

**Note**: to access items within the Container see {@link #cfg!itemId #itemId}.

items.name: prototype
items.text: Allows the addition of properties to all objects of type Object.

items.name: rendered
items.text: Indicates whether or not the component has been rendered.

items.name: scrollFlags
items.text:
An object property which provides unified information as to which dimensions are
scrollable based upon the {@link #cfg!scrollable #scrollable} settings (And for *views* of trees and
grids, the owning panel's {@link Ext.panel.Table#cfg!scroll Ext.panel.Table#scroll} setting).

Note that if you set overflow styles using the {@link #cfg!style #style} config or
{@link Ext.panel.Panel#cfg!bodyStyle Ext.panel.Panel#bodyStyle} config, this object does not include
that information. Use {@link #cfg!scrollable #scrollable} if you need to access these flags.

This object has the following properties:

items.name: x
items.text:
`true` if this Component is scrollable
horizontally - style setting may be `'auto'` or `'scroll'`.

items.name: y
items.text:
`true` if this Component is scrollable
vertically - style setting may be `'auto'` or `'scroll'`.

items.name: both
items.text:
`true` if this Component is scrollable both
horizontally and vertically.

items.name: overflowX
items.text:
The `overflow-x` style setting, `'auto'`
or `'scroll'` or `''`.

items.name: overflowY
items.text:
The `overflow-y` style setting, `'auto'`
or `'scroll'` or `''`.

items.name: self
synthetic
items.text:
This property is `true` if the component was created internally by the framework
and is not explicitly user-defined. This is set for such things as `Splitter`
instances managed by `{@link #cfg!border border}` and `box` layouts.

items.name: tabGuardAfterEl
items.text:
This element reference is generated when `{@link #cfg!tabGuard #tabGuard}` is `true`. This element
is generated after all `{@link #cfg!dockedItems dockedItems}` in the DOM.

items.name: tabGuardBeforeEl
items.text:
This element reference is generated when `{@link #cfg!tabGuard #tabGuard}` is `true`. This element
is generated before all `{@link #cfg!dockedItems dockedItems}` in the DOM.

items.name: tabGuardTpl
items.text:
This template is used to generate the `{@link #cfg!tabGuard tabGuard}` elements. It is used once per
element (see `{@link #property!tabGuardBeforeEl #tabGuardBeforeEl}` and `{@link #property!tabGuardAfterEl #tabGuardAfterEl}`).

items.name: validRefRe
items.text: Regular expression used for validating `{@link #cfg!reference reference}` values.

items.name: zIndexManager
items.text:
Only present for {@link Ext.Component#cfg!floating Ext.Component#cfg-floating} Components after
they have been rendered.

A reference to the ZIndexManager which is managing this Component's z-index.

The {@link Ext.ZIndexManager} maintains a stack of floating Component z-indices, and also provides
a single modal mask which is insert just beneath the topmost visible modal floating Component.

Floating Components may be {@link Ext.Component#method!toFront Ext.Component#toFront} or {@link Ext.Component#method!toBack Ext.Component#toBack} of the
z-index stack.

This defaults to the global {@link Ext.WindowManager} for floating Components that are
programatically {@link Ext.Component#method!render Ext.Component#method-render}.

For {@link Ext.Component#cfg!floating Ext.Component#cfg-floating} Components that are added to a
Container, the ZIndexManager is acquired from the first ancestor Container found
that is floating. If no floating ancestor is found, the global
{@link Ext.WindowManager} is used.

See {@link Ext.Component#cfg!floating Ext.Component#cfg-floating} and {@link #property!zIndexParent #zIndexParent}

items.name: zIndexParent
items.text:
Only present for {@link Ext.Component#cfg!floating Ext.Component#cfg-floating} Components which were
inserted as child items of Containers, and which have a floating Container in
their containment ancestry.

For {@link Ext.Component#cfg!floating Ext.Component#cfg-floating} Components which are child items of a
Container, the zIndexParent will be a floating ancestor Container which is
responsible for the base z-index value of all its floating descendants. It
provides a {@link Ext.ZIndexManager} which provides z-indexing
services for all its descendant floating Components.

Floating Components that are programmatically {@link Ext.Component#method!render Ext.Component#method-render} will not have a `{@link #property!zIndexParent zIndexParent}`
property.

For example, the dropdown {@link Ext.view.BoundList} of a ComboBox which is in a Window will have the
Window as its `{@link #property!zIndexParent zIndexParent}`, and will always show above that Window, wherever the Window is placed in the z-index stack.

See {@link Ext.Component#cfg!floating Ext.Component#cfg-floating} and {@link #property!zIndexManager #zIndexManager}

items.name: $border-width-threshold
items.text:
The maximum width a Panel's border can be before resizer handles are embedded
into the borders using negative absolute positions.

This defaults to 2, so that in the classic theme which uses 1 pixel borders,
resize handles are in the content area within the border as they always have
been.

In the Neptune theme, the handles are embedded into the 5 pixel wide borders
of any framed panel.

items.name: $panel-ignore-frame-padding
items.text:
True to ignore the frame padding.  By default, the frame mixin adds extra padding when
border radius is larger than border width.  This is intended to prevent the content
from colliding with the rounded corners of the frame.  Set this to true to prevent
the panel frame from adding this extra padding.

**Note:** This var is not applicable to IE8 & IE9.
